title: 110_s1473
content: The Act is titled the "Madera Water Supply Enhancement Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Madera Water Supply Enhancement Act" defines key terms such as District, Project, Secretary, and total cost related to the Madera Water Supply Enhancement Project in California. The Project involves a groundwater bank on the Madera Ranch to store and recover water. The Project cost should not exceed $90,000,000 and will involve acquiring land for the groundwater bank on the Madera Ranch. The Project cost should not exceed $90,000,000 and will involve acquiring land for the groundwater bank on the Madera Ranch. SEC. 3. NO FURTHER STUDIES OR REPORTS. Congress finds that numerous studies have been conducted regarding the Project, including technical reviews, groundwater bank reports, economic analysis, feasibility studies, and reports on geohydrologic and engineering feasibility. The curr_chunk provides a list of reports related to the Madera Ranch Water Supply Enhancement Project, including engineering feasibility, geologic and hydrologic testing, wetlands delineation, groundwater monitoring, and environmental impact assessments. These reports were conducted between 2000 and 2006. The Ranch Oversight Committee in November 2006 determined that no further studies or reports related to the feasibility of the Madera Ranch Water Supply Enhancement Project are needed as it is deemed feasible according to the Reclamation Act of 1902. The Project authorized by this Act will be carried out through a cooperative agreement between the Secretary and the District, outlining the District's responsibilities for engineering, design, construction, and contract administration. Additionally, the Madera Water Supply and Enhancement Project is authorized. The Secretary is authorized to enter into a cooperative agreement with the District for the design and construction of the Project. The Federal share of the Project's costs shall not exceed 25 percent, with in-kind services by the District considered part of the local cost share. The District will receive credit for costs incurred in the Project and the fair market value of lands used. The Secretary will not fund operation or maintenance, which will be the District's responsibility. Plans and analyses must comply with federal law before design or construction. The Secretary will utilize existing plans and analyses prepared by the District for the Project, ensuring compliance with Federal laws. The assistance provided does not transfer title, responsibility, or liability to the United States. $22,500,000 or 25% of the total Project cost is authorized for appropriation to the Secretary. SEC. 6. SUNSET: The Secretary's authority under this Act will end 10 years after its enactment.
